article.title: Higher-Order Interactions in Quantum Optomechanics: Application of Operator Method

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the figure illustrate about the normalized inequivalence δΔ/Ω of sideband frequency detunings in relation to intracavity photon number (n¯) and coherent phonon number (m¯)?
choices: δΔ/Ω increases linearly with both n¯ and m¯.
δΔ/Ω is independent of both n¯ and m¯.
δΔ/Ω increases nonlinearly with n¯ and m¯.
δΔ/Ω decreases with increasing n¯ and m¯.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main difference between the simulations using linearized and higher-order optomechanics models shown in this figure?
choices: Linearized models accurately predict the second-order mechanical sidebands.
Higher-order models show better agreement with experimental results, especially in predicting the shape and amplitude of the noise spectrum.
There is no noticeable difference between the two models.
Linearized models predict a much wider noise spectrum than higher-order models.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the violet colored v-shaped region in the left panel of the figure represent?
choices: Linearly and nonlinearly stable optomechanical interaction.
Linearly stable, but nonlinearly unstable optomechanical interaction.
Linearly unstable, but nonlinearly stable optomechanical interaction.
Linearly and nonlinearly unstable optomechanical interaction.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does equation (5) demonstrate about the sideband inequivalence (δ∆) in standard optomechanics?
choices: δ∆ is always zero, implying equal red and blue detunings.
δ∆ is independent of the optomechanical interaction rate (g0).
δ∆ is dependent on both intracavity photon (n¯) and coherent phonon (m¯) populations.
δ∆ only becomes significant when the mechanical frequency (Ω) is much larger than the optical decay rate (κ).
